item.description:
This hike will take place approximately 45 minutes after the hike at Fort Foster ends so the starting time is approximate as some of us on the Fort Foster hike will leave there to go to the Mt. Agamenticus hike which is approximately 15 miles/35 minutes away from Fort Foster.

We will start from the summit parking lot and hike approximately 5 miles or less depending on how the group is feeling (especially those who has already done the Fort Foster Hike).

Although you don't have to have signed up for the Fort Foster Hike to go on this one if you haven't gone to it you might want to call a number(s) to be determined and posted here closer to the actual hike to find out the exact starting time.

Taken from wikipedia:

The Mount Agamenticus region covers nearly 30,000 acres (121 km²) in the southern Maine towns of Eliot, Ogunquit, South Berwick, Wells and York. It is now a park reservation which provides habitat for wildlife and a venue for recreation.

Mount Agamenticus is also affectionately known as "Big A," the former ski slope's nickname. Not high as mountains go at 692 feet (211 m) above sea level, but from its peak on a clear day one can see the skyscrapers of Boston to the south, Cape Elizabeth and the entrance to Casco Bay to the north and the Presidential Range, including Mount Washington, to the west. Looking out to sea, the Isles of Shoals - about 10 miles (16 km) off York and Boon Island - about 6 miles (10 km) from the coast are also clearly visible. Historically, it was "a noted landmark for sailors".[

Here is a link to a Mt. Agamenticus website where one can find a trail map and more information.

http://www.agamenticus.org/

Some of us will be going out to a buffet place after this hike in Portsmouth if you want to come join us.

group.name: Human Soles & Doggie Paws Hikers & Walkers of Manchester, NH

item.name: Mount Agamenticus - York, ME 5(?) Mile Hike (After Fort Foster)
